did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, National Affairs Division, Program Staff Files
did.abstract: The National Affairs Program Files span in date from 1955 to 1978 and comprise of the office files of David B. Carlson, Jr., John R. Coleman, Christopher F. Edley, Ronald T. Gault, Sanford M. Jaffe, Eamon Kelly and William Pincus. Highlights of the collection include Government and Law files on the Foundation's support for legal aid clinics, civil rights litigation and minority representation in the legal field. Each individual's files have been organized into its own series. David B. Carlson's files date from 1968-1971 and consist of subject files primarily concerning Urban and Metropolitan Development grantees and grant evaluations. John R. Coleman's files date from 1966-1967 and consist of grant reviews. Christopher F. Edley's files date from 1959-1972 and consist of chron correspondence and subject files relating to the Foundation's Government and Law grant making and work in the field of corrections. Ronald T. Gault's files date from 1969-1976 and consist mainly of correspondence and memoranda regarding Travel and Study Awards. Sanford M. Jaffe's files date from 1974-1978 and consist mainly of memoranda, meeting minutes, and proposals from the Foundation's Committee on Human Rights and Social Process. Eamon Kelly's files date from 1966-1970 and consist of chron correspondence, Board of Directors meeting minutes, correspondence, memoranda, reports, and background information on the North Carolina Fund. William Pincus's files date from 1955-1967 and consist of memoranda on budget and grant evaluations and his writings on topics such as legal education.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: This collection appears to have been combined from the office files of seven National Affairs program officers, although the provenance is unclear in that regard. Several boxes in the collection were misattributed to National Affairs. These include: •Three cubic feet of office files of William O. Sweeney, International Division (these were processed separately). •One cubic foot box was identified as originating from the Population program and was held for processing as part of that collection. •One box was identified as a PRI file misattributed to National Affairs, and was transferred to the Closed Grant Office for separate offsite storage. •Three boxes of files were identified as belonging to Robert B. Goldmann, and were held for later processing with additional National Affairs files originating from Mr. Goldmann. •One box was identified as investment files from the Office of the Treasurer and was held for separate processing as part of the office files of Roger G. Kennedy.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: David B. Carlson, Jr. served as a Program Advisor for the Urban and Metropolitan Development program between 1969 and 1971. He later worked for the Foundation as a consultant specializing in Community Development Corporations (1988).

John R. Coleman was a labor economist who earned a B.A at the University of Toronto and an M.A. and Ph.D from the University of Chicago. He joined the Foundation as Associate Director of Economic Development and Administration and, in 1966, became Program Officer in Charge of Social Development. He left the Foundation in 1967 to become President of Haverford College.

Christopher F. Edley was born on January 1, 1928. He received a B.A. in Political Science (1949) and a LL.B from Harvard Law School (1953). He joined the Foundation in 1963 as a Program Officer in Social Development with shared responsibility for the administration of justice program and a program to assist minority groups. He was the first African American Program Officer hired by the Ford Foundation. Mr. Edley moved to the Government and Law program in 1966 and in December of 1967 he was appointed Program Officer in Charge of the program. He left the Foundation in 1973 to become President of the United Negro College Fund. He died on May 5, 2003, at the age of 75.

Ronald T. Gault was a Program Officer in Social Development from 1969 to 1978, when left the Foundation to serve as an advisor to New York City Mayor Edward Koch. Shortly thereafter Mayor Koch appointed him Commissioner of Employment.

Sanford M. Jaffe earned a B.A. from Rutgers University and an LL.B. from Harvard Law School. Mr. Jaffe was the Program Officer in Charge of Government and Law from 1968 to 1983. He departed the Foundation in 1983 to become Director of the Dispute Resolution Center at New York University's School of Law. Eamon Kelly was born in New York City. He earned a B.A. from Fordham University and from 1960 to 1965 earned an M.A. and Ph.D in economics from Columbia University. Dr. Kelly joined the Ford Foundation in 1969 and served as Officer in Charge for the Office of Social Development. In 1977, he was appointed Program Officer in Charge for Program Related Investments. He left the Foundation in 1981 to become the 13th President of Tulane University.

William Pincus joined the Foundation as a Program Associate for the Public Affairs Division around 1955, and from 1965 to 1968 served as a Program Officer for Government and Law. Beginning in 1955 Mr. Pincus helped lay the groundwork for the Foundation's support for legal aid clinics at law schools. In 1969, Mr. Pincus became the first President of the Council on Legal Education for Professional Responsibility (CLEPR), a non-profit organization established by the Ford Foundation to support legal aid clinics.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged into seven series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The National Affairs Program Files span from 1955 to 1978. The collection is comprised of the combined office files of David B. Carlson, Jr., John R. Coleman, Christopher F. Edley, Ronald T. Gault, Sanford M. Jaffe, Eamon Kelly and William Pincus. Each individual's files have been arranged as a separate series.

The files are particularly illustrative of the Foundation's Government and Law Program from the 1950s to the 1970s. William Pincus, one of the earliest Foundation program officers in the area of government and law, helped establish the Foundation's role in supporting and funding legal aid clinics, which were intended to help the impoverished. This support for legal aid and legal education then led the Foundation over time to support civil rights litigation and attempts to improve minority representation in the legal field. For example the Foundation evaluated of a proposal to establish a National Indian Rights Association (1969) to potentially improve the status of Native Americans in American society.

Other Foundation efforts toward improving the presence of minorities in education were made through grant Travel and Study Awards. Many awards to minority scholars were intended to support research such as a study of African Business (1972-1973) or a book on the student civil rights movement of the 1960s (1974). In addition, Dr. Eamon Kelly's files shed light on the Foundation's support for the North Carolina Fund, which was a series of state-sponsored experimental poverty relief programs in the late 60s.

This collection also shows the interrelation between program areas within the same division, particularly in the files of Christopher Edley who transferred from Social Development to Government and Law. As part of the Social Development unit Mr. Edley oversaw grants for civil rights housing litigation, and after transferring oversaw grants to increase the number of minority lawyers. These were slightly differing approaches to the goals of relieving poverty and improving of minority civil rights.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Foundation's work in urban poverty began with the establishment of the Public Affairs Program in 1952. One of the goals of the new program was to strive toward greater equality of opportunity for minority groups. In 1965, a National Affairs Division was created to focus on some of the deep-rooted problems facing American society. The program areas under this new National Affairs Division included Social Development, and Urban and Metropolitan Development. The United States and International Affairs Program (USIAP) replaced the National Affairs Division in 1981 after a Foundation-wide reorganization.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Ford Foundation has title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

Christopher Edley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mr. Edley's files comprise the largest series in this collection. A limited amount of chronological correspondence is available for the period from July 1968 to March 1969. The largest group of records, Mr. Edley's subject files, have been arranged in alphabetical order. Mr. Edley's files reflect his position in charge of Government and Law grant-making, including documents related to the Foundation's work in the area of Corrections. The documents, which date between 1964 and 1973, include memoranda on prison education programs, correspondence about and results from a Foundation-funded survey of state correctional research capabilities, discussion papers, and background information.
